claim: Flublok contains 3x the hemagglutinin (HA) antigen content of standard-dose flu vaccines, which has been linked to greater immunogenicity vs standard-dose flu vaccines.
explanation: Four-panel figure showing geometric mean fold rise in antibody titers at 1 month post-vaccination (panels A and B for age groups 18–44 and 45–64 years, respectively) and geometric mean fold reduction (waning) at 6 months post-vaccination (panels C and D for the same age groups). Data are shown for four vaccines (Fluzone IIV4, Fluarix IIV4, ccIIV4, and RIV4) across six influenza strains (H3N2 egg, H3N2 cell, H1N1 egg, H1N1 cell, B/Victoria egg, B/Victoria cell, B/Yamagata egg, B/Yamagata cell). Error bars represent 95% CIs and p-values indicate comparisons versus standard-dose IIV4. Evidence: RIV4 (Flublok) exhibited significantly higher 1-month geometric mean fold rises in antibody titers versus standard-dose IIV4 vaccines for multiple strains (e.g., H3N2 egg and cell, H1N1 cell) with p<0.0001 in several comparisons. The figure does not support the claim that Flublok contains 3× the HA antigen content, as no antigen dose information is presented, although it does show greater immunogenicity of RIV4 versus standard-dose IIV4. Therefore, it does not support the claim in full. Note: The figure is clear on immunogenicity differences but provides no data on antigen content or dosing; image resolution is sufficient for interpreting the presented immunogenicity data.
